metadata.title: SARS-CoV-2 Detection in Different Respiratory Sites: A Systematic Review and 1 Corresponding Author: Summary

affiliation.institution: Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health

abstract.text: Background: The accurate detection of SARS-CoV-2 through respiratory sampling is 22 critical for the prevention of further transmission and the timely initiation of treatment for 23 COVID-19. There is a diverse range of SARS-CoV-2 detection rates in reported studies, 24 with uncertainty as to the optimal sampling strategy for COVID-19 diagnosis and 25 monitoring. 26 Methods: We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis of studies comparing 27 respiratory sampling strategies for the detection of SARS-CoV-2 RNA. The inclusion 28 criteria were studies that assessed at least two respiratory sampling sites 29 (oropharyngeal swab, nasopharyngeal swab, and sputum) in participants with COVID-30 19. The percentage positive tests were compared between sampling modalities by 31 constructing a Z-test assuming independence and using the standard errors obtained 32 from the random effects meta-analysis. 33 Findings: From 1039 total studies, we identified 11 studies that met our inclusion 34 criteria, with SARS-CoV-2 testing results from a total of 3442 respiratory tract 35 specimens. Compared to nasopharyngeal swab sampling, sputum testing resulted in 36 significantly higher rates of SARS-CoV-2 RNA detection while oropharyngeal swab 37 testing had lower rates of viral RNA detection. Earlier sampling after symptom onset 38 was associated with improved detection rates, but the differences in SARS-CoV-2 RNA 39 detection by sampling method was consistent regardless of the duration of symptoms.

40 Interpretation: The results support sputum sampling as a primary method of COVID-19 41 diagnosis and monitoring, and highlight the importance of early testing after symptom 42 onset to increase the rates of COVID-19 diagnosis. 43 44 All rights reserved. body_text.text: Worldwide, there are now over 3 million confirmed cases and 250,000 deaths due to detection rates with each of the diagnostic methods. In COVID-19 diagnosed 72 individuals, the reported SARS-CoV-2 detection rate has ranged from 25% to >70% of 73 collected nasopharyngeal swabs, 5,6 32% to 65% for oropharyngeal swabs, 2,5 and 48% 74 to >90% for sputum. 7, 8 This has led to significant uncertainty and confusion in the field 75 as to the reason behind the disparate testing results and the optimal diagnostic 76 sampling strategy for diagnosis and monitoring of COVID-19 patients. Search strategy and selection criteria 87 In this systematic review and meta-analysis, we used the Preferred Reporting Items for 88 Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) to review literatures and report our 89 results ( Figure 1) . A computerized search was implemented in PubMed, MedRxiv and 90 BioRxiv using a search term, "((COVID OR COVID-19 OR SARS) AND (throat OR nasal 91 OR nasopharyngeal OR oropharyngeal OR oral OR saliva OR sputum OR PCR))". The The estimated percentages of positive SARS-CoV-2 qPCR tests and the 95% 106 confidence intervals were calculated for each sampling strategy using random-effects 107 meta-analyses for binomial data using Stata Metaprop package. 9 We also performed an 108 analysis stratified by the duration of symptoms prior to the testing, with results 109 categorized as 0-7 days, 8-14 days, >14 days from symptom onset. FIGREF0.text: of viral transmission is through exposure to respiratory secretions of 50 close contacts 1 as the respiratory tract represents the major area of viral shedding. 2 The 51 accurate diagnosis of COVID-19 infection through respiratory sampling is critical for the 52 prevention of further transmission, clinical trial inclusion criteria and the timely initiation 53 of treatment. In addition to its importance in diagnosis, respiratory sampling plays a 54 central role in determining the duration of viral shedding, with implications for clinical 55 management of potentially infectious patients, decisions on the duration of social 56 isolation, and our understanding of viral transmission and pathogenesis. 3 57 58 Nasopharyngeal swabs are one of the most commonly used methods of respiratory 59 secretion sampling for the detection of SARS-CoV-2 viral RNA. However, the use of 60 nasopharyngeal swabs have a number of drawbacks, including that high-quality swab 61 samples are technically challenging to obtain, 4 nasopharyngeal swabbing increases the 62 risk to healthcare providers due to the frequent induction of reflex sneezing/coughing, 63 and the disruption in the supply of swabs, transport media, and personal protective 64 equipment (PPE). For all of these reasons, there is intense interest in the comparison of In the published literature, there has been a wide variance in the reported SARS-CoV-2 71

FIGREF1.text: 77 performed a systematic review of the literature and meta-analysis to compare the ability 78 of nasopharyngeal swabs, oropharyngeal swabs, and sputum to detect SARS-CoV-2 79 RNA. The results demonstrate that sputum had the highest rate of SARS-CoV-2 80 detection and oropharyngeal swab had the lowest. In addition, much of the variability 81 between reported results in the literature can be attributed to differences in the 82 underlying participant population, with the higher levels of detection for those earliest in 83 the COVID-19 disease course.

FIGREF3.text: 92 search was completed through April 30, 2020. In addition, we reviewed the reference 93 sections of relevant articles. We included studies that assessed at least two respiratory 94 sites of sampling performed by healthcare workers for individuals with confirmed 95 COVID-19. When numerical results were not reported or further clarification was 96 needed, we contacted the corresponding authors for additional information.

FIGREF4.text: (AM, EE) screened the citations and three authors (AM, EE, YL) 99 independently extracted data from the included studies. In the 11 studies included in 100 this meta-analysis, we extracted summary estimates from tables or texts from four 101 studies. For the other nine studies, we were able to obtain individual-level data from the 102 manuscripts or study authors.

FIGREF8.text: with 3442 respiratory samples were included in this analysis, 132 including results from 1083 oropharyngeal swabs, 1299 nasopharyngeal swabs and 133 1060 sputum samples. By sampling method, the estimated percentage of positive 134 samples was 43% (95% confidence interval [95% CI]: 34-52%) for oropharyngeal 135 swabs, 54% (95% CI: 41-67%) for nasopharyngeal swabs and 71% (95% CI: 61-80%) 136 for sputum (Figure 2A-C). The rate of SARS-CoV-2 detection was significantly higher in 137 sputum than either oropharyngeal swabs or nasopharyngeal swabs (Figure 2D). 138 139 Among the 11 studies, 6 provided details on the time of sampling after symptom onset, 140 including results from 540 oropharyngeal swabs, 759 nasopharyngeal swabs, and 487 141 sputum samples. For all sampling methods, rates of SARS-CoV-2 detection was highest 142 early after symptom onset. For oropharyngeal swab sampling, the estimated percentage 143 of positive tests were 75% (95% CI: 60-88%) between days 0-7, 35% (95% CI: 27-43%) 144 between days 8-14 and 12% (95% CI: 2-25%) after 14 days from symptom onset 145 (Figure 3A). For nasopharyngeal swabs, the estimated percentage positive was 80% 146 (95% CI: 66-91%), 59% (95% CI: 53-64%) and 36% (95% CI: 18-57%) at 0-7 days, 8-14 147 days and >14 days after symptom onset, respectively (Figure 3B). For sputum, the 148 estimated percentage positive was 98% (95% CI: 89-100%), 69% (95% CI: 57-80%), 149 and 46% (95% CI: 23-70%) at 0-7 days, 8-14 days, and >14 days after symptom onset, 150 respectively (Figure 3C). For every time period, sputum had the highest percentage of 151 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF10.text: of sample positivity was highest in sputum specimens and lowest in 164 oropharyngeal swabs. We detected heterogeneity between the reported results by 165 study, much of which could be accounted for by differences in the timing of respiratory 166 sampling. For all three sampling modalities, we found that the likelihood of a positive 167 result declined with longer time since symptom onset. Regardless of the time frame 168 studied, sputum consistently had the highest positive rates while oropharyngeal swabs 169 had the lowest.

FIGREF11.text: -CoV, the disease manifestation of SARS-CoV-2 is largely in the lower 172 respiratory tract. 16,17 Prior studies have noted a higher rate of SARS-CoV-2 detection 173 and viral loads in lower respiratory tract samples, such as bronchoalveolar lavage fluid 174 and endotracheal aspirates, compared to upper respiratory tract specimens. 2,3 These 175 results are concordant with the far higher density of the SARS-CoV-2 viral target, the 176 human angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) receptor, in pneumocytes and in lower 177 airway epithelial cells compared to epithelial cells in the upper airway. 18,19 The higher 178 SARS-CoV-2 detection rates in sputum samples likely relate to their origin, which is 179 derived at least partially from the lower respiratory tract. This suggests that sampling of 180 only upper respiratory tract samples, e.g., using nasopharyngeal swabs, may lead to 181 missed diagnosis of COVID-19 and an inaccurate assumption of SARS-CoV-2 viral 182 clearance that dictates the duration of social isolation and return to work policies. 183 184 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF12.text: and thus requires high-level personal protective equipment for healthcare 189 workers, which are in short supply. Finally, there is a global shortage of nasopharyngeal 190 swabs and transport medium that necessitates the search for potential alternative 191 methods for the sampling of respiratory secretions. In addition to our finding of improved 192 detection of SARS-CoV-2 RNA, the use of sputum sampling removes the need for 193 difficult to obtain swabs, improves patient acceptance, and increases the chances of 194 sample self-collection by the patient, which would decrease the risk to healthcare 195 workers. Furthermore, the higher sensitivity of sputum for the detection of COVID-19 is 196 also supported by previously reported studies on the detection of non-COVIDof this meta-analysis is that the majority of participants in these studies 200 enrolled hospitalized patients and it is unclear how the results may differ for individuals 201 with asymptomatic infection or only mild symptoms. However, there are reports that 202 rates of nasopharyngeal, oropharyngeal, and sputum positivity may not be substantially 203 altered in those with mild symptoms versus those with severe disease. 12 A potential 204 limitation with the use of sputum is that not all COVID-19 patients are able to 205 expectorate sputum, which may be reflected by the lower number of tested sputum 206 samples in the included studies compared to nasopharyngeal or oropharyngeal swabs.

FIGREF14.text: , the results were generally consistent within most studies and we 214 were able to dramatically reduce the detected heterogeneity of the studies by215    comparing results by timing of symptom onset.216 217 In summary, this systematic review and meta-analysis demonstrates that compared to 218 nasopharyngeal swab sampling, sputum testing resulted in significantly higher rates of 219 SARS-CoV-2 RNA detection while oropharyngeal swab testing had lower rates of viral 220 RNA detection. Earlier sampling after symptom onset was associated with improved 221 detection rates, but the differences in SARS-CoV-2 RNA detection was consistent 222 between sampling strategies regardless of the duration of symptoms. The results 223 support the use of sputum testing as a primary method of COVID-19 diagnosis and 224 monitoring.
